thread.title_full: South Carolina coach Steve Spurrier explains decision to resign

author: courier-journal.com
title: South Carolina coach Steve Spurrier explains decision to resign
text:
COLUMBIA, S.C. – True to form, Steve Spurrier matter-of-factly announced his resignation Tuesday – not retirement – as South Carolina's football coach and said he was looking forward to the next chapter of his life.
"The last several years I always get asked how much longer are you going to coach," Spurrier said in a news conference at Williams-Brice Stadium. "My answer is always the same. As long as we keep winning, everybody’s happy we’re ranked, I guess I can go several more years. But if it starts going south, it starts going bad, I need to get out. You can’t keep a coach who’s done it as long as I have when it goes the wrong direction."
USA TODAY
How Steve Spurrier left a permanent stamp on college football
Spurrier, 70, made it clear that South Carolina's performance this season and downward trend that began last season was the reason he felt the need to step aside. Though he is the winningest coach in school history at 86-49 and posted three consecutive 11-2 seasons from 2011-2013, the Gamecocks slipped to 7-6 last season and speculation began to swirl that Spurrier was considering retirement.
Re-energized by an Independence Bowl victory over Miami, Spurrier returned this season and fired back at critics question how much longer he wanted to coach, vehemently saying he could go several more years and that he felt good about this year's team.
With South Carolina starting 2-4, however (including 0-4 in the SEC), Spurrier did not want to continue and acknowledged that he had become a recruiting liability because of his age.
Follow the road to the 2015 College Football Playoff at The Football Four , our home to rate and debate the nation's best. "Somehow or another, we’ve slipped," Spurrier said. "It’s my fault. I’m the head coach. It’s time for me to get out of the way."
Spurrier, who won the 1996 national championship at Florida and leaves as the second-winningest coach in SEC history, said he began to sense that it was time to leave after a Sept. 26 victory against Central Florida in which the Gamecocks struggled. He said he made up his mind Sunday after a 45-24 loss to LSU.
Though school president Harris Pastides and athletics director Ray Tanner asked Spurrier to consider staying to finish out the season, he did not feel that would be effective in helping turn the season around.
FOR THE WIN
Steve Spurrier's 15 greatest trash-talking Quote: s
"I find that doesn’t work a lot," Spurrier said. "If players know you're not going to be their coach, you just don’t have the accountability. It gives us a chance to hire an interim head coach. I think it’s time for the team to hear a new message from another coach. It gives us a little time to start rebuilding. When something is inevitable, I believe you do it right then."
Spurrier didn't completely close the door on coaching in some capacity again or consulting, though he said he would not be a head coach in college.
"I didn't plan on going out this way," he said. “Nothing goes on forever. I’ve gone on a lot longer than most people.”
Shawn Elliott, the Gamecocks’ co-offensive coordinator and offensive line coach, will take over as interim head coach for the rest of the season.
